s.text: The announcement was buried in the president's weekly radio address of Dec. 4. After boasting, "We've changed the culture of welfare from one that fostered dependence to one that honors and rewards work," Clinton unveiled three new "high-performance bonuses"--extra money that will be used as a carrot to induce states to do certain things.

The announcement was buried in the president's weekly radio address of Dec. 4. After boasting, "We've changed the culture of welfare from one that fostered dependence to one that honors and rewards work," Clinton unveiled three new "high-performance bonuses"--extra money that will be used as a carrot to induce states to do certain things.
But wait a minute.

The announcement was buried in the president's weekly radio address of Dec. 4. After boasting, "We've changed the culture of welfare from one that fostered dependence to one that honors and rewards work," Clinton unveiled three new "high-performance bonuses"--extra money that will be used as a carrot to induce states to do certain things.
It's hard to deny that this pride is, in some sense, a good thing.

* If you read the fine print, the "bonus," which amounts to $20 million, is to go to the states that show the greatest "improvement" in the percent of low-income working families receiving food stamps.

* If you read the fine print, the "bonus," which amounts to $20 million, is to go to the states that show the greatest "improvement" in the percent of low-income working families receiving food stamps.

* If you read the fine print, the "bonus," which amounts to $20 million, is to go to the states that show the greatest "improvement" in the percent of low-income working families receiving food stamps.

* If you read the fine print, the "bonus," which amounts to $20 million, is to go to the states that show the greatest "improvement" in the percent of low-income working families receiving food stamps.
Pushing food stamps on poor people is unlikely to move people off of welfare because food stamps are welfare.
One will reward states that enroll more poor children in Medicaid.

If the administration wants to get more money to the working poor--as it should--why not do it through measures restricted to the working poor, like an expanded EITC and a higher minimum wage, rather than through food stamps?
The working poor are the group of eligible recipients who are most likely to stigmatize the receipt of welfare.
Pushing food stamps on poor people is unlikely to move people off of welfare because food stamps are welfare.
One will reward states that enroll more poor children in Medicaid.

If the administration wants to get more money to the working poor--as it should--why not do it through measures restricted to the working poor, like an expanded EITC and a higher minimum wage, rather than through food stamps?
The working poor are the group of eligible recipients who are most likely to stigmatize the receipt of welfare.
Pushing food stamps on poor people is unlikely to move people off of welfare because food stamps are welfare.
This represents a small but telling victory for those Democrats--I call them Money Liberals--for whom getting cash to the poor, not upholding the work ethic, is the most important thing.
One will reward states that get more poor children into two-parent families.
Pushing food stamps on poor people is unlikely to move people off of welfare because food stamps are welfare.
Clinton seems to be ignoring one of the hard-won lessons of liberalism's collapse, which is that programs to help poor workers should actually be restricted to workers.
Not to live well, of course, but the problem of dependency has never been about people living well.
It happened in the late 1960s, when state and local officials embarked on a campaign to encourage welfare and food-stamp use--to remove stigma and boost "participation rates."

Indeed, you can make no attempt to even find a job or support your family, and you'll still qualify for $230 a month in food stamps (for a two-person family) or $329 (for a three-person family) or $419 (for four).
Sure enough, Clinton declared food stamps "critical supports," and vowed to "hold states accountable and make sure families get the benefits they need."
In practice, how could the government hope to destigmatize food stamps for the former group but not for the latter group (who are, under law, also entitled to them)?
In practice, how could the government hope to destigmatize food stamps for the former group but not for the latter group (who are, under law, also entitled to them)?
Low-income workers, especially, have been reluctant to sign up for the benefits to which they are legally entitled.
It tells you that food stamps are respectable, that you're a fool not to go down and claim what you're entitled to.
In practice, how could the government hope to destigmatize food stamps for the former group but not for the latter group (who are, under law, also entitled to them)?
Low-income workers, especially, have been reluctant to sign up for the benefits to which they are legally entitled.
It tells you that food stamps are respectable, that you're a fool not to go down and claim what you're entitled to.
In practice, how could the government hope to destigmatize food stamps for the former group but not for the latter group (who are, under law, also entitled to them)?

To qualify for a bonus under his new regulations, states would be required not just to make it easy for families who leave welfare (TANF) to keep getting food stamps, but to actively "encourage food stamp applications even if the TANF application halts."
There is a word for cashlike benefits you can get whether you work or not.
Low-income workers, especially, have been reluctant to sign up for the benefits to which they are legally entitled.
In southern states, this food-stamp benefit typically exceeds the regular monthly TANF benefit.
And food stamps are a peculiar benefit, in that, if you have children, you can get them whether or not you work.
Shouldn't we encourage those people to stay on welfare, albeit at a lower benefit level, rather than make a harsh, clean break?
But in a welfare program, the same benefit levels apply to workers and non-workers alike.

Clinton's Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), which proposed the regulations implementing the new food-stamp bonuses, says they will promote the goal of "ending the dependence of needy parents on government benefits."
Sure enough, Clinton declared food stamps "critical supports," and vowed to "hold states accountable and make sure families get the benefits they need."
